p: For the most part, prior to the outbreak in Reunion Island in 2005, CHIKF in children and the very young typically involved biphasic fever and rash with the occasional description of pain and/or hemorrhage ( Table 1) [ 17, 18, 19, 26, 27]. Although neonatal and pediatric seizures and other CNS symptoms were reported in children during the early outbreaks, the onset of such symptoms was invariably linked with fevers greater than 104 Â°F [ 5, 17, 19, 26, 29].
